This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan, in Washington.
The season of transatlantic fashion shows is underway - New York last week, London this week, then onto Paris and Milan.

All feature stoic models, garbed in the latest designs for next fall, which include oversized, vinyl tablecloth dresses, shirts made of trash bags, a black-and-white maid's uniform, and tall fur hats worthy of Dr. Seuss.
From the eccentric to the outlandish, the fashion industry sets the tone for what we should be wearing.
Of course, a lot of people couldn't care less what's hot on the catwalk, and a lot more blanch at the price tags or the designs or both.
So what differentiates the fashionable from the rest of us?
Does runway fashion matter?
Does it influence your style or not?
E-mail is talk@npr.org.
Later in the program, from fashion to toys and the meaning and the marketing behind the acronym KGOY.
But first, does fashion matter?
We begin with Robin Givhan, fashion editor of The Washington Post, who joins us from our studios in New York City.
Nice to have you on TALK OF THE NATION today.
It's great to be here.
And I note in your articles reviewing some of the shows in New York, you pointed out some of those outrageous things that we mentioned in the introduction.
Of course, you pointed out some much kinder words for many other things, too.
(Soundbite of laughter)
But as you looked - as you look at some of these outrageous things, does anybody actually ever wear these clothes?
Well, I think, you know, the simple answer to that is does anyone really wear the most outrageous things?
No. But a lot of those things that are put on the runway that are outrageous aren't necessarily put there for someone to buy and then, you know, march down K Street wearing.
Mm-hmm.

A lot of it is really about trying to experiment and trying to give an artistic vision about how they see people dressing in the next season, and sometimes they use extreme measures to make their point.
Mm-hmm.
And it was interesting to me that these designers are sponsored.
They have sponsors.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Someone is actually paying for them to do this.
Yes.
I'm surprised you don't see STP on the back of some of these dresses.
Oh, of course some of those dresses don't have backs.
Well, and may be a subject for another day.
Nevertheless, what still gets back to the point, what separates these very high-end items from wearable clothes?
(As Amelia, reading) A rumbling sound, then three sharp knocks, ababa dook dook dook.
Because it's not two worlds to me.
I don't even think about it like that.
Keeping my integrity is what I think about it.
You just do your job and you do it well, and you keep your integrity.
And I don't sing anything I wouldn't be able to sing in front of my children.
I don't sing anything I wouldn't be able to sing in front of my pastor.
People fall in love whether you're, you know, at the church or if you're in the club.
You do fall in love the same way - the feelings, the emotions, the things that it brings from the inside of who you are, it's the same.
And I want to be sure that I sing about love and not sex.
Let me talk about that with you for a moment because that's a really fine line, isn't it?
It is in that I think people blur the lines of what's OK to say.
I believe the line is very clear.
Really?
It's very clear.
Even in your CD, this new one that you have, which is ""Love the Woman,"" and the photograph of you on the cover which is, you know, very lovely, but it suggest to me and I'm not a...
(Soundbite of laughter)
You know, I'm not a bible thumping person at all, but it would suggest to me that there are some churches in America where that picture of you on the cover would be trouble.
(Laughing) Yeah.
Well, I wouldn't wear that to church, that is true.
(Soundbite of laughter)
But, that really is the bigger struggle for me than anything, is what I wear.
Really?
Absolutely.
What I sing is easy.
Why is that?
You can sing about love all day long and have a really pretty voice, and have a sexy quote unquote ""sexy voice,"" but not sing about sex and still emote those kind of feelings.
(Soundbite of song ""First Kiss"")
(Singing) Do you feel what I feel When you kiss me like that.
I'm not sure if it's love.
I just know you (unintelligible) And it feels like ooohh la la la la...
And listening to this, and I've listened to it several times, you - well, let me put it this way, when you listen to the whole thing, how does it feel to you?
(Laughing) Well, it's one of my favorite things to do is to listen to my record before it comes out.
That's the first thing because it's before the judgment calls have come, and I tell you, I enjoyed listening to this record so much.
(Soundbite of song ""It Ain't Supposed to be this Way"")

(Singing) Do you remember the last time we shared a laugh It seems like forever 'cause now I hardly ever see you smile I've never been the fool to think love don't cost a little pain I don't think it's suppose to be this hard, Ooh, to get along, to get along...
It Ain't Suppose to be this Way,"" is the song that is the song that is the one you hear when you click on your Web site.
Is that because that's the one you guys want to push?

I felt like it was a good balance of the R&B and the jazz connection between both sides because I think if we went with ""First Kiss,"" which I absolutely love too, it would have lent it more to the jazz side of the album, and the R&B crowd might not have come to it with the awareness that it's more R&B stuff on there also.
